18.24. For a group G, a function ϕ : G →R is a quasimorphism if there is a least non-negative number D(ϕ) (called the defect) such that |ϕ(gh)−ϕ(g)−ϕ(h)| ⩽ D(ϕ) for all g, h ∈ G.
A quasimorphism is homogeneous if in addition ϕ(gn) = nϕ(g) for all g ∈ G. Let ϕ be a homogeneous quasimorphism of a free group F. For any quasimorphism ψ of F (not required to be homogeneous) with |ϕ − ψ| < const, we must have D(ψ) ⩾ D(ϕ)/2. Is it true that there is some ψ with D(ψ) = D(ϕ)/2?
M. Burger, D. Calegari
